BE

Nomura is to close its European equity research division, axing hundreds of jobs in London and the US, according to people familiar with the matter, as Japan’s largest brokerage struggles to turn a profit from its international operations.
The move is another setback in Nomura’s campaign to climb into the top rungs of global investment banking — an effort supposedly boosted by the 2008 purchase of the Asian and European operations of Lehman Brothers.

AstraZeneca PLC (AZN:LSE): Last: 4,026, down 39 (-0.96%), High: 4,033, Low: 3,993, Volume: 956.57k

PM

11:17 am
BE

As late-stage trials often do, though investors never seem to price in that probability very well.

BE

Now Goldman's talking about a cash call to turn around the franchise..

BE

We view current long-term consensus estimates for AZN (to 2020) as overly
optimistic; for 2020, we are 10%/25% below consensus on revenues/EPS.
Over 2016-18, given underlying cash generation, existing leverage and
commitments to capex/dividend, we see limited balance sheet flexibility for
big M&A. We believe AZN earnings benefit disproportionately (vs. peers)
from milestones, out-licensing and asset divesture near term. Excluding
these (GSe core) implies AZN is trading at 23x 2017E P/E and discounting an
IRR of 9%-12% on R&D investments (vs. peers at 2%-3%), which we believe
skews the risk-reward against investors. We lower to Sell, from Neutral.

11:18 am
BE

Our analysis of AZN’s cash generation from 2016-18 suggests it will need to
raise c.$5-$8bn of cash, e.g. via asset divesture, incremental out-licensing or
debt raising, to fund its existing commitments to M&A, dividends and
ongoing capex. We also see risks to 2020 company consensus revenue
estimates for Brilinta (we are 46% below) and its diabetes portfolio (we are
18% below). Consensus also currently models an 88% flow-through on
AZN’s incremental product revenues between 2015-2020 to operating
margins, which we view as optimistic (GSe 73%). We believe c.70%-75% of
AZN’s 2020 revenue base will still be sourced from primary care products,
thus requiring continued SG&A support. While encouraging, we believe
AZN’s pipeline is likely to need significant R&D investments in the near
term, thus limiting operating margin expansion (relative to consensus).

PM

Hmm

PM

Pretty opportunistic sell

BE

11:24 am
BE

Also digs into whether AZN's core cashflow is really core.

BE

Such as the cash it gets from Movantik, the rights over which it bought from Nektar Therapeutics in 2009.

BE

Similar licencing deals don't look awfully like core AZN, it argued, and inflate the figures quite a bit.

11:26 am
BE

In 2015, AZN entered into a collaboration with Innate Pharma to develop Innate’s
anti-NKG2A antibody (IPH2201) and made an upfront payment of $250mn (plus potential
developmental/regulatory/sales milestones of up to $1bn, in addition to tiered double-digit
royalties on sales). AZN did not record this upfront $250mn as a part of its core P&L.
Also, when AZN out-licensed the haematological development rights to its PD-L1 inhibitor
durvalumab to Celgene and received $450mn as upfront payments, this $450mn was
recognised as core income (recorded as externalisation).
From broader perspective, we note that, since the start of 2013, AZN has signed around 12 agreements relating to acquisitions/purchase of commercial rights to assets for a
cumulative cost of $11.7 bn. None of these have impacted its reported “core” EPS

BE

You get the idea. Good bit of research, to my mind. Gritty.

11:38 am

Michael Stewart at Panmure -- a man with a lively view -- is selling Ted Baker.

Ted Baker PLC (TED:LSE): Last: 2,579, down 56 (-2.13%), High: 2,600, Low: 2,550, Volume: 151.45k
PM

(V interesting BornCynic )

11:38 am
BE

Difficult to trade, is Ted Baker. But it's also a consensus buy across the City.

BE

Let me grab a bit.

BE

Several highly-rated consumer stocks have capitulated over the last quarter,
reporting weak like-for-like sales growth over the comparative period. We think
Ted Baker (TED) will be the next. Our analysis shows that TED’s underlying sales
densities in each of the territories it operates in appear negative in the latter half of
the prior financial period. Our valuation analysis shows the shares to be worth
1902p, a circa 28% discount to the prevailing market price; we therefore initiate on
the stock with a Sell recommendation.

11:39 am
BE

 Ted Bakers FY2016 results masked a diminishing rate of sales growth. Whilst a
13.6% increase in full year group retail sales on an increase in average square footage
of 7.5% implies healthy density growth over the entire period, our analysis shows that
group retail sales lagged space growth by 0.4pp through 2H2016.
 Retail sales include Ecommerce revenue, however. As the group generated £30.6m
of ecommerce sales in the latter half of FY2016, the implied level of sales from the
store estate is £149.7m, a 3.9% increase over the comparative period. If average
square footage increased by 8.5% through 2H2016, underlying sales densities must
have fallen by circa 4.6% year-on-year.
 Particularly poor retail sales in the UK and Europe. Despite a 30.7% increase in
ecommerce sales during the aforementioned period, overall retail sales grew by just
4.1% year-on-year to £131.6m. Store revenues, which form almost 80% of UK retail
sales, fell by 1.0% despite the fact that average square footage for the geography
increased by 3.6% year-on-year.
 Retail sales haven’t just deteriorated in the UK and Europe. Store revenue increased
by just 15.2% in North America on an increase in average square footage of 16.4%
and by 30.0% in AMEA, broadly in-line with space. Reported sales densities appear
therefore either flat or down in each of the three territories TED operates in towards
the end of the prior reporting period.
 Our cash flow analysis shows Ted Baker’s intrinsic worth to be c£919m. With 40.0m
shares in issue, the value of the business on a per share basis equates to 1902p per
share. This implies that the shares are currently trading at circa 38% premium to their
fundamental worth.

BE

All of which is pretty aggressive, though difficult to argue with.

Anglo American PLC (AAL:LSE): Last: 616.20, up 31.1 (+5.32%), High: 640.00, Low: 583.90, Volume: 5.80m

11:41 am
PM

http://www.investe...1604120800028532U/

Yup, diamond demand picking up.

PM

Yeah, positive news shock

11:42 am
BE

Though the phrase "diamond demand picking up" is a phrase that doesn't necessarily chime with the current mood.

BE

Here's UBS to summarise where we are.

BE

Strong Sight #3 of 2016: sales up 7% m/m to US$660m
Anglo American has reported that the provisional value of rough diamond sales for the
third sales cycle (Cycle 3) of 2016 (which ended last week) was US$660m. This is a 7%
increase on the Cycle 2 sales value of US$617m. The value quoted includes Global
Sightholder Sales (DBSS) and Auction Sales, so the total of the 10 sights in 2016 should
equal the revenue reported by De Beers for 2016. De Beers revenue is typically
weighted to H1 (55:45 split); we estimate revenue for 2016 at ~US$5.5bn based on
average revenue in Jan/Feb/Apr (and assuming no increase in rough prices), up 13% y/y
(2015 $4.7bn) and above UBSe of $4.8bn.
De Beers cautious looking forward due to seasonality; next sight 16-20 May
Philippe Mellier, Chief Executive of De Beers Group, said: "So far, 2016 has seen
significantly stronger rough diamond demand than that experienced at the end of 2015
as the actions taken by the industry continue to have a positive effect. However, we are
now moving into a part of the year where rough diamond demand has historically been
lower as a result of seasonality, so we continue to adopt a prudent mindset." The next
sight in the DBSS part of the business is from 16-20 May.
Cut prices broadly flat, rough +2-3%; rough inventory still high at producers
Polished diamond prices have been stable since February, up ~3% from the trough at
end-Oct according to Rapaport; this suggests the market has stabilised after the
challenging H2-15. In our opinion, meaningful rough diamond price increases appear
unlikely near-term due to high inventories at producers (we estimate De Beers inventory
at ~15m cts at end-15 vs norm of ~5mcts and 2015 production of 29m cts).

11:43 am
BE

Stays neutral.

BE

Our £4.00/sh tgt is based on 0.4x NPV (unchanged) to reflect the high balance sheet
risk in a lower-for-longer price environment and execution risk with restructuring. In
our opinion, the stabilisation in the diamond market and modest recovery in platinum
prices (on the back of gold) at the start of 2016 is encouraging. As detailed in our
downgrade note of 7-Mar, we do however remain cautious on the fundamentals for
Platinum and Diamonds. In line with previous company statements, we still expect
Anglo to provide an update on the sale of Niobium & Phosphates in H1-16; we see this
as a small positive catalyst as detailed in our note of 7-Mar.

PM

For what it's worth -- according to one of my daughters who is in the jewellery trade -- Hatton Garden diamond people have been stocking up PA on diamonds over the past six months.

11:44 am
PM

Just a punt.

PM

But the jewellery business itself has collapsed since Xmas

BE

If you want to know about diamond prices, I find the worst people to talk to are diamond people.

11:45 am
PM

PM

I said something similar to Lili

BE

We've talked here a lot about the supply chain and credit being withdrawn to polishers and blah, blah, blah. Google it if you're really interested, ROTR.

11:46 am
BE

Instead, here's RBC.

BE

It's a start: In 2015 De Beers total sales of natural diamonds declined to
$4.1bn from $6.5bn the previous year as demand slumped in the face of
excess polished inventory. De Beers' volume sales fell 39% to 19.9m cts
(32.7m in 2014). While average prices achieved increased 5%, this was a
result of mix as De Beers reported that its rough index declined 15% in
2015. This mirrors the experience reported by Alrosa. In 2015 De Beers'
H2 sales fell to $1.4bn from $2.7bn in H1 as De Beers held back goods and
reduced prices to help restore some stability to the midstream. Holding
back sales helped the market to start clearing excess rough inventory,
with shortages developing in certain categories and some prices materially
stronger. Our understanding is that in the second sales cycle DBAS fetched
prices on some categories materially higher than those in Sight sales. This
was probably also true of independents who would have benefited from
retrained sales from De Beers and Alrosa.
Caution is the key: The actions of De Beers and Alrosa have been a positive
for the diamond trade and laid the foundation for more stable conditions
in the midstream. We remain cautious on prices overall this year until
it is clear that polished demand is recovering. We still model prices off
~5% this year but if De Beers and Alrosa remain patient there may be
scope for a more positive outcome. Supporting our caution, we note the
comment from De Beers' CEO Phillippe Mellier this morning: “However,
we are now moving into a part of the year where rough diamond demand
has historically been lower as a result of seasonality, so we continue to
adopt a prudent mind-set.”

BE

And Caz.

11:46 am
BE

Upside to JPMe H1’16 forecasts: $1.8bn of YTD sales at De Beers
represents 100% of our H1’16 forecast and 45% of our FY’16 forecast.
Thus, there is clear upside to our H1 forecasts. However, we note that we
have assumed a 45/55 split for FY’16, in contrast to a more typical 55/45
split in previous years, reflecting our view that market normalisation
would take some time to come through. Until we get more details on
production and sales volumes with the Q1 production report next week
(Thu 21st) which will allow more insight into value per carat etc. it is
difficult to assess the implications against our $4.1bn FY’16 revenue
forecast which is broadly flat YoY.
 Negative thesis on AAL predicated on commodity price downside
risk, balance sheet and lack of asset sales progress: Our negative view
on AAL is based on a view that YTD positive macroeconomic
momentum, particularly in China, will dissipate, putting pressure on
commodity prices and ultimately causing the balance sheet and funding
concerns that plagued the shares in 2015 and early 2016 to re-emerge.
We are also yet to see concrete progress on $3-4bn of targeted asset
disposals in 2016, which are key to addressing balance sheet concerns
and believe the market needs to see some evidence that management are
able to generate reasonable sales values before the benefit of the doubt
can be given.

BE

Valuation is more supportive, but retain UW: AAL trades on spot
EV/EBITDAs of 5.5/4.7x for FY’16-17E, in-line with RIO as the
cheapest of the diversifieds in FY’16, but at a ~10% discount in FY’17E.
FCF yields of 5.6-10.7% are also competitive, while a base case P/NPV
of 0.61x is the cheapest among the peer group. We retain our UW
recommendation at this juncture, with risks around commodity prices,
balance sheet and asset sales still elevated and not adequately reflected in
the share price in our view.

11:57 am
PM

Let me share some Credit Suisse on this

PM

The read-across for soft luxury players is negative. Organic sales for
the key Fashion & Leather Goods division were flat against our and market
expectations of +3%, decelerating from +3% in 4Q and +6% in 2015. We
are therefore cautious on Burberry (U/P) and Kering (U/P) reporting on 14
and 21 April (see Further growth deceleration in 1Q for our previews).
■ The staples/retail assets saved group organic growth in 1Q. Perfumes
& Cosmetics grew organic sales by +9%, although it was helped by a
fragrance launch at Dior. Organic growth for Selective Retailing came in at
+4% with a sharp contrast between strength at Sephora and weakness at
DFS. The +6% organic growth for Wines & Spirits seems to confirm that
destocking in China is really over. The exposure to the staples/retail
portfolio growing at +6% in 1Q is unique to LVMH in our coverage universe
and the primary reason for our positive stance on the stock (see Preference
for LVMH over Richemont).

PM

Growth in hard-luxury reaccelerated. The Watches & Jewellery division
recorded organic growth of +7% accelerating from +3% in 4Q. We reckon
Tag Heuer and Bvlgari both contributed to the improvement. This should
somewhat reassure the market after weak Swiss watch exports YTD and
the slowdown of the jewellery category in 4Q, which was also experienced
at Richemont (N).
■ The US strength may be LVMH specific. The regional breakdown will
only be disclosed before the conference call tomorrow at 3pm CET. LVMH
flagged a strong US market but we reckon this is mainly driven by Sephora
and VS/VSOP cognac and not necessarily by the luxury brands. We note
that the staples/retail portfolio accounted for 2/3 of US sales in 2015.

11:58 am
PM

PM

But the general signal is negative

11:59 am
PM

New Costa boss at Whitbread I see

PM

BE

Yep. The exit of Chris Rogers isn't something anyone was calling for.

12:00 pm
BE

Costa's slowing down because it's old and big. Not because it's been mismanaged.

BE

The only readthrough, really, is on whether Dominic Paul is the man to spin off Costa.

BE

And .......... no.

12:01 pm
BE

If that were the plan, at least in the next two years, you'd have thought keeping Rogers onboard would've been the way to go.

PM

that's a point

BE

Credit Suisse says shrug.

12:02 pm
BE

■ Costa management change should be no surprise: Whitbread has
announced that Chris Rogers, the MD of Costa, will be stepping down from
the Board as of 20 April (leaves group 1 July). He will be succeeded by
Dominic Paul who joins on 6 June from Royal Caribbean International. We
believe Chris Rogers was rightly seen as the most credible internal candidate
for the Group CEO role which became available in 2015 but, given that role
was filled externally by Alison Brittain, we are not surprised to see this
subsequent evolution in the team. We don’t believe this in any way reflects
the more recent slower LFL sales growth at Costa.
■ Significant management change but broadened skill set: Whilst we are
unsurprised by this morning's news we acknowledge it is the latest in a
series of changes, which has certainly been a focus for investors: Chairman
appointed Sept-14 (although on Board since Sept-09), CEO appointed Sept-
15, CFO appointed Nov-12, MD Whitbread Hotels & Restaurants appointed
Mar-15. Whilst the company has certainly lost a lot of internally generated
knowledge/talent, we believe the Board has sought to bring news skills to the
group especially as it embarks on an ambitious and more internationally
focused phase of growth. It is interesting to note Dominic Paul brings
experience from RCI in Asia/China as well as significant operational
experience from the airline industry (including bmi, BA and easyJet).
■ Catalysts: FY results 26 April.
■ Target price implies 34% potential upside: Our DCF/SOTP derived TP
implies 34% potential upside and with the Feb-17E PE of 15.3x implying a
PEG of 1.5x we retain a positive view and reiterate our Outperform rating.

BE

Simon French at Cenkos says similar.

BE

Royal Caribbean who joins on 6th June. Dominic appears to have significant experience of operating in China which continues to offer significant growth potential given Costa has less than 500 shops there, a fraction of Starbucks. Chris will leave on 1st July having spent over 11 years with the company, first as Finance Director and since 2012, as MD of Costa. We believe that a spin off of Costa is less likely in the short-term meaning value continues to be trapped within the group acting as a brake on the share price.
